journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: A one-dimensional model for heat release rate and emission formation in diesel engines based on correlations for entrainment rate, lift-off length and ignition delay: Validation for transient conditions

contrib-group.aff: KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden

author-notes.corresp: Anders Westlund, Internal Combustion Engines, KTH Royal Institute of Technology, SE-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden. Email: anders.westlund@avl.com

abstract.p: A simplified one-dimensional model for combustion and emission formation in diesel engines has been developed in a project where the long-term objective is to predict the emissions during transient operation. The models are intended to be used as a tool for pre-development of after-treatment systems and for offline calibration of engine controls. These applications imply that the final model must be both computationally inexpensive and comprehensive. The model is based on a correlation for the air entrainment rate which is applied to a discretized injection event. On this, the combustion rate and the emission formation rate are imposed with simple models. In this publication, the model is validated for the targeted conditions and transient operation. The model is based on a previously presented model which was evaluated for steady state conditions. The model presented here has been modified to address the shortcomings that were identified in the previous evaluation. The model was able to predict the heat release rate and the emissions of nitrogen oxide (NO) and soot with reasonable accuracy and also the requirement regarding the computational time was met. The average time for simulation of one engine cycle was approximately 3 s on a standard laptop.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Engine modelling is becoming increasingly important to engine manufacturers during the development phase. The driving factor is the complex construction and control systems that are needed for engines to meet the most stringent emission legislations. Also, the development in computer technology has allowed more extensive use of modelling as a part of the development and use of models that were considered too complex only a few years ago. Engine models are used in a range of applications such as gas exchange, acoustics, component design and combustion development. For the latter, more complex combustion models, typically, computational fluid dynamics (CFD) are used for the design of components, e.g. pistons and cylinder heads, to reduce the number of prototypes. However, these models are too computationally demanding for today’s computers to be useful in applications such as the pre-development of after-treatment systems and optimization of engine controls. There is a great potential in using models in these applications if the models are simple and fast but yet still sufficently accurate to predict the effects of various parameters. The work in this publication is the final part of a project with the long-term objective to meet this demand. As the main goal for most engine manufacturers is to pass the legislated test procedure, the objective in this project was to identify or develop models that can predict the emissions of nitrogen oxide (NO) and soot over a test cycle, e.g. the European Transient Cycle.

Many simplified emission models have been proposed over the years. Among the simplest NO models are power-law correlations where the NO emission is modelled as a function of the in-cylinder temperature and/or exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) rate (see, for example, the work by Andersson1). For NO modelling, multi-zone models have been widely used (see, for example, the work by Ericson2 and Egnall3). Typically, in these models, one zone consists of fresh gases and one or more zones contains the combustion products. The NO formation is then calculated in the zone(s) with products. With this approach, more factors affecting the NO formation rate can be considered. Owing to the complexity of soot formation and oxidation, simple soot emission models are less common but can be found. Unlike the temperature-dependent NO emission, there is no single factor correlating to soot emissions and therefore no easy way to model it. Hiroyasu4 proposed a model where the soot formation rate is a function of the temperature and the pressure in the combustion chamber and the oxidation rate is a function of the temperature, the pressure and the oxygen concentration. This approach has been employed by, for example, Hountalas et al.5 who used a multi-zone framework with equilibrium chemistry, i.e. similar to the previously described NO models. However, Hountalas et al. used a three-dimensional model. Also, a number of multi-step models have been proposed. In these, the different mechanisms in soot formation are modelled, i.e. nucleation, coagulation, surface growth and agglomeration. Examples of proposed multi-step models are those which have been described by Tao et al.6,7 and Leung.8 Kaario et al.9 proposed a model for soot formation which mimics the results from the complex model presented by Kitamura et al.10 and describes the formation rate as a function of the air-to-fuel ratio, the temperature and the pressure.

The proposed model presented here is a one-dimensional model where the entrainment of gas into the fuel jet, the lift-off length and the ignition delay are estimated from correlations. The injection event is discretized and the fuel from each step is considered as a ‘zone’. All zones are traced over time with respect to the axial distance from the injector nozzle. The equivalence ratio in each zone is estimated with the correlation developed by Naber and Siebers11 and Siebers.12,13 The correlations for lift-off length and ignition delay are used to determine when combustion occurs in the zones. When combustion does occur, the temperature in each zone is calculated as the adiabatic flame temperature. With the equivalence ratio and the temperature modelled in each zone, emission formation is calculated. NO formation is calculated with a simple kinetic reaction system including the Zeldovich mechanism. The method used to model soot formation is similar to the method used by Kaario et al. The soot formation rate is estimated from the results of Kitamura’s model, i.e. as a function of the equivalence ratio and the temperature. Soot oxidation is modelled with an OH mechanism. Also, a simple model for the heat release rate can be implemented by assuming mixing-controlled combustion (and using the correlations for the lift-off length and the ignition delay). A purely mixing-controlled heat release rate has been used before (see, for example, the paper by Chmela et al.14) but was not based on the correlations used here.

An initial validation of the model was presented in a previous publication,15 where the model was validated for conditions where only one parameter was varied at a time. The evaluated parameters were the EGR rate, the engine speed, the injection timing and the injection pressure. The results showed that the model was able to predict most of the effects on the heat release rate and the engine-out emissions but not all. The model’s main advantage is the use of well-known correlations for the entrainment rate, the lift-off length and the ignition delay, which makes it computationally efficient and robust.

In the work presented here, the identified shortcomings were addressed and the model is validated for the target conditions, i.e. transient operation. Modelling combustion and emission formation can be more challenging because of the extreme conditions that can occur. Also, the engine settings were adjusted according to the control unit of a production engine, which means that several parameters are changed simultaneously. The main improvements are that the effects of swirl are implemented and that a variable particle diameter is used.

sec.title: Experimental set-up
sec.p: The measurement of validation data from transient operation is challenging since several important instruments have response times that are greater than one engine cycle. Therefore, the uncertainty in the validation data (both the model inputs and the model outputs) is significantly higher in transient operation than in stationary operation. To address this issue, a new approach was used here; the operating conditions and engine settings of a Euro V engine were measured during transient operation and then mimicked in a single-cylinder research engine operating at steady state. The engine was operated in load transients at three engine speeds (1000 r/min, 1400 r/min and 1800 r/min) from about 150 N m to the maximum load at each speed. Even though the components (the piston and the injection system) in the single-cylinder engine are almost identical with those in the Euro V engine, the conditions will not be exactly the same for several reasons.

list-item.p: Since the single cylinder is operated in the steady state, the engine temperature cannot be matched.
The bore and stroke are similar but not identical.

There is some uncertainty regarding the operating conditions that were measured during the transients in the production engine because of the response times of the instruments used, e.g. the EGR rate and λ.

sec.p: Also, because of a malfunctioning pressure sensor in the production engine, the exhaust back pressure was not matched perfectly. After the experiment, it was found that the exhaust back pressure measured in the Euro V engine was consequently too low, i.e. the single-cylinder engine was operated with a lower back pressure than the production engine was. However, the validation data measured in the single-cylinder engine are considered to be representative for transient conditions in most aspects. The main advantage of this manoeuvre is that the model inputs are correctly matched to the measured emissions.
The specifications of the production engine and the single-cylinder engine are given in Table 1.

caption.p: Engine specifications.

sec.p: In the single-cylinder engine measurements, soot emissions were measured with a filter smoke meter (AVL 415) and converted to grams per kilogram of fuel via a correlation developed by Arcoumanis et al.16 The measurement uncertainty of the smoke meter as measured by the filter smoke number is 0.05, which is relatively high for an engine that is certified for Euro V. The uncertainty in the correlation used by Arcoumanis et al. was not estimated in the range used here. The NO emission was measured with an exhaust gas analyser (Horiba EXSA 1500) which is accurate to within 1% of the full range (3000 ppm).

The most important information about the transient measurements in the Euro V engine is the response times for the instruments that were used to evaluate the operating conditions. The response time is the time needed to change from one level to another, not including the time before the instrument starts to change which can be corrected for (transport delay). The relative air-to-fuel ratio λ was measured with a wideband unit during the transients in the production engine. The EGR rate was estimated on the basis of the volumetric efficiency, a method estimated to be accurate to within 5% units. The EGR and λ measurements are estimated to have a response time of a few engine cycles (two to five). The measurements of the inlet pressure are assumed to be cycle resolved. The inlet temperature measurements are much slower but, since the inlet temperature did not seem to vary significantly (observed in steady state operation), this is not considered to be critical. All engine settings were logged cycle by cycle.

Emissions were also measured in the Euro V engine during transient operation to evaluate the correlation to the emissions measured in the single-cylinder engine operated in the steady state. For these measurements, a NOx sensor (MEXA 120NOx) and an opacimeter (AVL 439) for soot were used. These instruments have response times of approximately five to ten engine cycles.

sec.title: Heat release rate and emission modelling
sec.p: This section describes the correlations, theories and reactions that were used in the model and how they were implemented.

which is the velocity excluding losses (equation (2)), corrected with the velocity coefficient
C
v
, i.e. including losses. The radial velocity component is calculated according to equation (6). The axial velocity component initially dominates in the zones, until it is reduced by the entrainment of gas into the zones. The radial velocity component contributes significantly in the late part of the entrainment process and dominates the in-cylinder motion after the end of injection.

The heat release is modelled by assuming that, after the ignition delay period and downstream from the lift-off length, the cumulative heat release in each zone is proportional to the energy of the fuel that can be combusted with the entrained oxygen. However, the energy of the fuel that is bound as soot is not released until the soot is oxidized.

The temperature in the flame was approximated as equal to the ambient temperature until the zone’s axial distance from the injector was greater than the lift-off length and until the end of the ignition delay period. When both conditions are fulfilled, the temperature in the zones is estimated as the adiabatic flame temperature for the (individual) conditions in the zones until the equivalence ratio is below 1. After that, the temperature in the zones decreases owing to the expansion of the combustion chamber and to the mixing with the surrounding gases.

The adiabatic flame temperature is calculated with an iterative function that finds a temperature where the enthalpy of the products equals that of the reactants at the starting temperature. Only the six main combustion products are considered for this calculation: carbon dioxide (CO2), water (H2O), nitrogen (N2), O2, carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen (H2). The composition of the combustion products are calculated with a system of equations considering the balance of carbon atoms (C), hydrogen atoms (H), oxygen atoms (O) and nitrogen atoms (N) in the reactants and products, and the equilibrium concentrations from the reactions in the equations

For the zones where the combustion is fully premixed, i.e. the equivalence ratio is lower than 1 at the start of combustion, the adiabatic flame temperature is used in the first time step after the start of combustion. After that, the temperature is calculated as for not fully premixed zones and conditions with equivalence ratios lower than 1.
The heat release rate is calculated as

sec.title: Gaseous reactions
sec.p: In order to minimize the calculation time for the model, a significantly reduced reaction system was composed. The requirement was that it should produce the correct formation rates for NO and OH, since the latter is the oxidizer for soot in this model. To control the need to meet this requirement, the reaction scheme was tested and, when all reactions had stabilized, the fractions of NO and OH were compared with the equilibrium fractions from the book by Heywood22 for a range of conditions. The reactions and reaction rates were obtained from the NIST database23

As an ordinary differential equation solver is too time consuming for the intended application, a discrete solution system was attempted. However, owing to the fast reaction rates, very short time steps were necessary to avoid crashing. The reaction scheme was therefore solved semi-analytically, i.e. the formation rates were calculated explicitly with the analytical solutions for each species. Assuming that the other species are constant from the previous time step, the concentration of each species was solved as an ordinary differential equation.

The initial compositions in the zones were assumed to be the products (i.e. CO2, H2O and N2) from complete combustion of the fuel which can combust with the entrained gases (including EGR) and the remaining fuel. Thereafter, more combustion products are mixed into the zones in each time step, proportional to the amount of fuel that has combusted (the amount of fuel decreases accordingly). When the equivalence ratio in the zones is below one, O2 is also mixed into the zones.

sec.title: Soot formation
sec.p:
The soot formation model was inspired by Leung,8 who used simple equations to resemble the complex process. Kaario et al.9 looked at the results of Kitamura et al. and developed a simple model that gave similar results, a bell-shaped peninsula in the
ϕ
–T plane with a maximum soot yield around 1800 K and increasing yield for equivalence ratios higher than 2. However, a slightly different formulation for soot formation was used in this model and another oxidation model is used. The soot formation rate is modelled with the equation

where
ϕ
is the equivalence ratio,
p
is the pressure and
m
fuel
is the fuel mass. The proportionality constant
C
was adjusted to give the same absolute value as the results obtained by Kitamura et al. for n-heptane.
C
was set to 0.07 (corrected from 0.05 in our previous publication15). The temperature term
K
T
is

Soot oxidation. According to Ezekoye and Zhang,24 soot oxidation
( d
m
soot
/ d t ) |
ox
by OH can be modelled as

where Γ is the collisional efficiency which was set equal to 0.1,
X
OH
is the molar fraction of OH molecules, T is the temperature and
A
s
is the surface area of soot (m2) which is calculated by converting the mass of soot to the volume and then to the surface area. This conversion includes assumptions regarding both the soot density and the average particle diameter and, since these are difficult to estimate with accuracy, the conversion factor from the mass to the surface area was determined empirically, i.e. it was used as a tuning parameter. In an initial validation of the model,15 it was shown that it was necessary to model the average particle diameter as a function of the injection pressure. This conclusion was based on the observation that soot emissions were underpredicted at low injection pressures and vice versa. The function was found by tuning in the average particle diameter at different injection pressures and fitting a second-order polynomial to the data. It has been confirmed by measurements (see, for example, the work by Ochoterena25 and Mathis et al.26) that the size of the primary particles decrease with increasing injection pressure. The fitted function is shown and demonstrated in Figure 1. Also shown is the injection pressure in the validation data measurements and the corresponding modelled average particle diameter.

caption.p: The modelled average particle diameter as a function of the injection pressure.

sec.p: The second-order polynomial shown in Figure 1 was used only in the range of injection pressures that are shown in the figure. For injection pressures lower than 1250 bar, the particle diameter was not increased further. No condition with an injection pressure greater than 2500 bar was tested.

The agreement between the modelled soot emissions and the measured soot emissions with and without a variable particle diameter is shown in Appendix 1. The ratio of the modelled soot emissions to the measured soot emissions is shown versus the EGR rate, the engine speed, the injection timing and the injection pressure. The purpose of these plots is to demonstrate that no trends remain between these parameters and the accuracy of the predictions, i.e. that the effects of the parameters are modelled correctly.

The same type of plot is also shown when the radial velocity component from swirl is not included. This plot shows that the soot emissions are overpredicted when swirl is not considered. However, the average particle diameter used must also be considered. In the previously presented initial validation,15 where swirl was not included, a constant average particle diameter of 20 nm was tuned in at an injection pressure of 1250 bar. As shown in Figure 1, the particle diameter used at the same pressure is significantly higher.

sec.title: Summary of model inputs and outputs
sec.p: This section contains a summary of the inputs and outputs to the model. The engine specific inputs are summarized in Table 2.

caption.p: Engine specific inputs.

tr.td: Bore; stroke; connecting-rod length; compression volume; bowl diameter
Valve timing (intake closing and exhaust opening); mean swirl number
Number of nozzles per injector; nozzle diameter; flow coefficients (Cd, Cv and Ca); opening–closing characteristics (relationship between solenoid activation and needle opening)
Ignition delay; lift-off length; spray spreading angle
Spray spreading angle; average particle diameter; injector opening and closing characteristics

sec.p:
Most of the engine specific inputs are fairly straightforward to find and most of the correlation constants were adopted directly. However, some minor tuning was necessary. Besides the previously mentioned particle diameter, the tuning parameters used were the spray spreading angle
c
in equation (5) and the opening–closing characteristics of the injector. The spray spreading angle was reduced slightly compared with the suggested values, as this was found to improve overall agreement between the measured heat release rate and the modelled heat release rate. The opening–closing characteristics were estimated from an investigation made by Lindström and Ångström.17 For all high-load conditions, the same delays (from solenoid activation or de-activation to the start of injection or the end of injection) and opening and closing slopes were used, as shown in Figure 2. However, for the low-load cases, the delay for needle closing was reduced to match the total injected amount of fuel in each case.

caption.p: The injector characteristics and normalized injection rate (opening delay, SOIlat = 0.425 ms; opening slope, SOIrmp = 0.9 ms; closing delay, EOIlat = 1.05 ms; closing slope, EOIrmp = 0.5 ms).
ESOI: electronic start of injection; SOIlat: start of injection; SOIrmp: start of injection ; EEOI: electronic end of injection; EOIlat: end of injection; EOIrmp: end of injection.

sec.p: Compared with the investigation by Lindström and Ångström,17 the opening slope and closing delay are longer (approximately 0.65 ms opening delay and approximately 0.9 ms closing delay in the work by Lindström and Ångström17). Correcting these parameters was justified since their measurements were performed in atmospheric conditions. Also, an injector with a larger nozzle diameter (163 µm) was used in their investigation. However, since no direct measurements of the injection rate into the cylinder were available, the correction was made by adjusting the parameters to obtain the overall best agreement between the measured and modelled heat release rates and the total injected mass. It is therefore possible that this correction compensates for a shortcoming in the entrainment model during the initial part of the injection. As previously described, entrainment is estimated with a correlation developed for the steady part of the injection, i.e. not considering the effects of the transient injection rate. However, the same corrections could be used in all high-load cases, i.e. in a wide range of conditions, which support the validity of the corrections.
The cycle specific inputs in Table 3 and the model outputs are shown in Table 4.

caption.p: Operating condition inputs.

tr.td: Engine speed; temperature, pressure and EGR rate of the inducted charge
Injection pressure; ESOI; solenoid activation time

fn.p: EGR: exhaust gas recirculation; ESOI: electronic start of injection.

caption.p: Model outputs.

sec.title: Validation experiment
sec.p: The validation data were measured in a single-cylinder research engine operated with the conditions and the engine settings that correspond to transient operation in a Euro V engine. The transient performance of the Euro V engine was evaluated at three different engine speeds: 1000 r/min, 1400 r/min and 1800 r/min. The load was increased from about 150 N m to the maximum load at each engine speed. The measurements were repeated four times at each engine speed and the data were used to calculate the averages and standard deviations for the measured parameters. For each speed, six individual engine cycles during the transient were selected as validation cycles.

The average torque, the EGR rate and λ during the transient at 1000 r/min are shown in Figure 3. Also shown are the standard deviations for the parameters and the selected engine cycles for each engine speed.

caption.p: The torque, λ and the EGR rate during the load transient at 1000 r/min. Also shown are the standard deviations for the measured parameters and the engine cycles selected for evaluation.
EGR: exhaust gas recirculation.

sec.p: The selected engine cycles are as follows:

list-item.p: when the EGR valve is closed and the engine operates without EGR;
when the EGR valve is re-opened;

sec.p: The engine cycles were selected according to the same criteria for 1400 r/min and 1800 r/min, as shown in Figure 4 and Figure 5 respectively.

caption.p: The torque, λ and the EGR rate during the load transient at 1400 r/min. Also shown are the standard deviations for the measured parameters and the engine cycles selected for evaluation.
EGR: exhaust gas recirculation.
The torque, λ and the EGR rate during the load transient at 1800 r/min. Also shown are the standard deviations for the measured parameters and the engine cycles selected for evaluation.
EGR: exhaust gas recirculation.

sec.p: The operating conditions and engine settings in these six engine cycles (18 in total) were then used in the single-cylinder research engine. However, the exact same conditions were not always achieved. As previously described, there are some differences between the Euro V engine and the single-cylinder research engine, e.g. the cylinder volume, the exhaust back pressure and the engine temperature. The operating conditions and engine settings for the selected engine cycles in the single-cylinder research engine at 1000 r/min, 1400 r/min and 1800 r/min are summarized in Table 5, Table 6 and Table 7 respectively.

caption.p: Settings for the selected engine cycles at 1000 r/min.

EGR: exhaust gas recirculation; ESOI: electronic start of injection; CA: crank angle: ATDC: after top dead centre.

caption.p: Settings for the selected engine cycles at 1800 r/min.

tr.th: Value for the following selected cycles

fn.p: EGR: exhaust gas recirculation; ESOI: electronic start of injection; CA: crank angle: ATDC: after top dead centre.

sec.p: As discussed in the section on the experimental set-up, there are important differences between the transient conditions in the Euro V engine and the steady state conditions in the single-cylinder research engine. To evaluate how these differences affect the emissions, the transient and steady state emission measurements were compared for the 1000 r/min case. The results are shown in Figure 6 together with the standard deviations of the transient emission measurements.

caption.p: The NO emissions and opacities measured during the transient at 1000 r/min and the corresponding emissions measured in the steady state in the single-cylinder engine.
NO: nitrogen oxide.

sec.p: Figure 6 shows that there are significant differences regarding the emissions. However, it was considered that the measurements in the single-cylinder research engine are representative of the transient conditions in most aspects. Also, even though there are differences, the steady state measurements are considered to have a higher accuracy, regarding both the emissions and the operating conditions, which is important from the viewpoint of model validation.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In this section, the model is validated with the measurements from the 18 selected engine cycles operated in the single-cylinder research engine, i.e. according to Tables 5, 6 and 7. However, in the low-load case (selected cycle 1) at 1000 r/min, the engine was operated with a pilot injection. Since only a single injection was implemented in the model, this was handled by increasing the duration of the main injection to match the total amount of injected fuel.
As the modelled heat release rate is an indicator of how correct the combustion process is modelled, this aspect of model validation is presented first.

sec.title: Heat release rate
sec.p: The modelled heat release rate is shown for one of the engine cycles with the best agreement to measured data (selected cycle 6; 1400 r/min) in Figure 7. Also shown are the injector solenoid activation (electronic start of injection) and de-activation (electronic end of injection) and the modelled injection rate. The data are normalized. The corresponding cumulative heat release and injection are shown in Figure 8.

caption.p: The normalized heat release rates (measured and modelled) and injection rates. Also shown are the injector solenoid activation (ESOI) and de-activation (EEOI).
ESOI: electronic start of injection; EEoI: electronic end of injection; HRR: heat release rate; CAD: degrees crank angle.
The cumulative normalized heat release rates (measured and modelled) and injection rates. Also shown are the injector solenoid activation (ESOI) and de-activation (EEOI).
ESOI: electronic start of injection; EEoI: electronic end of injection; HRR: heat release rate; CAD: degrees crank angle.

sec.p: The overall agreement for all the evaluated engine cycles is shown in Figure 9. The agreement is evaluated by comparing the crank angle where 10% of the cumulative heat released is reached (CA10), the crank angle where 50% of the cumulative heat released is reached (CA50) and the crank angle where 90% of the cumulative heat released is reached (CA90).

caption.p: The overall agreement between the measured and the modelled cumulative heat release rates, shown as CA10, CA50 and CA90.

CAD: degrees crank angle; CA10: crank angle where 10% of the cumulative heat released is reached; CA50: crank angle where 50% of the cumulative heat released is reached; CA50: crank angle where 90% of the cumulative heat released is reached.

sec.p: The low-load cycle at 1000 r/min with pilot injection reached 10% cumulative heat release before the start of the main injection and before 0° CA. This 10% point is not included in Figure 9. The predictions for when 10% and 50% of the cumulative heat release are reached agree well with the measurements but there is more spread for the 90% predictions. However, no systematic errors were identified. A plot showing the ratio of the modelled 90% cumulative heat release to the measured 90% cumulative heat release versus the EGR rate, the engine speed, the injection timing and the injection pressure can be found in Appendix 1.

sec.title: Emissions
sec.p: The modelled emissions are validated separately for each engine speed. The modelled and measured NO and soot emissions for the six engine cycles at 1000 r/min, 1400 r/min and 1800 r/min are shown in Figure 10, Figure 11 and Figure 12 respectively.

caption.p: The measured and modelled emissions for the selected engine cycles at 1000 r/min.
NO: nitrogen oxide.
The measured and modelled emissions for the selected engine cycles at 1400 r/min.
NO: nitrogen oxide.
The measured and modelled emissions for the selected engine cycles at 1800 r/min.
NO: nitrogen oxide.

sec.p: The overall agreement for the predicted emissions in all the evaluated engine cycles is shown in Figure 13 and Figure 14 for soot and NO respectively. Also shown are the measurement uncertainties (described in the section on the experimental set-up).

caption.p: Overall agreement between the measured and modelled soot emissions for the selected engine cycles. Also shown is the measurement uncertainty.
The overall agreement between the measured and modelled NO emissions for the selected engine cycles. Also shown is the measurement uncertainty.
NO: nitrogen oxide.

sec.p: The predicted NO emissions agree well with the measurements and the soot emission predictions agree reasonably well. Similar to the heat release rate predictions, the emission predictions were evaluated for systematic errors. In the previously presented evaluation,15 systematic errors were identified for the EGR rate, the engine speed and the injection pressure. However, with the modification presented here, no systematic errors remain. A plot showing the ratio of the modelled NO emissions to the measured NO emissions and the ratio of the modelled soot emissions to the measured soot emissions versus the EGR rate, the engine speed, the injection timing and the injection pressure can be found in Appendix 1.

sec.title: Summary and discussion
sec.p: The results show that the presented one-dimensional modelling approach predicts heat release rates, soot emissions and NO emissions which agree well with the measured data. However, there are some discrepancies as follows.

list-item.p: The modelled heat release rate agrees very well with the measured data during the first part of the combustion. The main discrepancies are found in the last part, after the end of injection. This could be because the entrainment correlation that is used was developed for the steady part of the injection. Another possible contributing factor is that evaluation of the heat release rate from measurements is more difficult during the last part of the combustion. The last part of the combustion is considered to be important for oxidation of soot. Therefore, the engine-out soot predictions could possibly be improved if this discrepancy was decreased.

The overall agreement of the emission predictions with measured data, especially the NO predictions, is reasonably good. Besides the previously mentioned issue with the last part of the combustion, there are mainly two possible reasons why the soot predictions agree less: soot formation and oxidation are more complex than NO formation but the used models are more simplified; the measurement techniques used for soot emissions have a relatively higher uncertainty. The presented uncertainty in Figure 12 is the uncertainty of the filter smoke meter used for soot measurements. However, the uncertainty in the function used to convert the measurements to the evaluated units (gram per kilogram of fuel) may introduce additional errors. The current accuracy of the soot model is approximately to within the uncertainty in the measurements. Therefore, it is not reasonable to improve the accuracy of the model before the measurement method is improved.

sec.p: Several possible improvements to the models could be suggested, e.g. a more detailed reaction system (gas phase and soot) or modifying the entrainment rate during the transient part of the injection. Based on the results, it appears that the steady entrainment correlation applies fairly well for the entire injection event. However, most of the cases evaluated here are relatively long injections where the injection profile is roughly square (top hat). The validity for other profiles or multiple injections (except for one low-load case) was not investigated.

Since such modifications (a more detailed reaction system or transient injection rate) would increase the calculation time of the models, the intended application must be considered. In some applications, the models must instead be simplified further. In this project, the objective was to develop a model that could be used as a computationally inexpensive tool for pre-development of after-treatment systems and/or optimization of engine control settings. The average computational time for one engine cycle, 3 s on a standard laptop, makes it usable for these applications.

app.title: Appendix 1
app.p: Figure 15, Figure 16 and Figure 17 show plots of the ratio of the modelled to the measured soot emissions, the ratio of the modelled to the measured NO emissions and the ratio of the modelled to the measured CA90 against the injection pressure, the inlet CO2 fraction, the engine speed and the electronic start of injection, with swirl and with a variable particle diameter. Figure 18 show plots of the ratio of the modelled to the measured soot emissions against the injection pressure, the inlet CO2 fraction, the engine speed and the electronic start of injection, with a constant particle diameter. Figure 19 show plots of the ratio of the modelled to the measured soot emissions against the injection pressure, the inlet CO2 fraction, the engine speed and the electronic start of injection, without swirl.
